MA 104: Ordinary Differential Equations - Lectures 9 & 10 (Combined)

Related: MA 104 Course Overview | Lecture 8 - MA104 | Lecture 11 - MA104

Power Series Solutions about the Initial Point

If initial conditions are given at $x = x0$ (where $P(x)$ and $Q(x)$ are analytic), seek solution $$ y(x) = \sum{k=0}^\infty ak (x - x0)^k $$

  • Or shift variable $\tilde{x} = x - x_0$ and solve about $\tilde{x}=0$.

Legendre‚Äôs Equation & Legendre Polynomials

Legendre‚Äôs equation (parameter $\alpha \in \mathbb{R}$): $$ (1 - x^2)y'' - 2x y' + \alpha(\alpha + 1)y = 0 \tag{1} $$ or equivalently $$ [(1 - x^2)y']' = -\alpha(\alpha + 1)y $$ Power series solution about $x=0$ (analytic coefficients): Assume $y(x) = \sum_{n=0}^\infty a_n x^n$. Recurrence: $$ a_{n+2} = -\frac{(\alpha - n)(\alpha + n + 1)}{(n+1)(n+2)} a_n, \quad n=0,1,2,\dots $$ Two independent solutions: $$ y_1(x) = 1 - \frac{\alpha(\alpha+1)}{2!}x^2 + \frac{(\alpha-2)\alpha(\alpha+1)(\alpha+3)}{4!}x^4 - \cdots $$ $$ y_2(x) = x - \frac{(\alpha-1)(\alpha+2)}{3!}x^3 + \frac{(\alpha-1)(\alpha-3)(\alpha+2)(\alpha+4)}{5!}x^5 - \cdots $$ Both converge for $|x| < 1$. Legendre polynomials $P_\alpha(x)$:
  • When $\alpha = n \in \mathbb{N}_0$, one solution terminates ‚Üí polynomial of degree $n$.
  • Normalize so $P_n(1) = 1$.
Rodrigues‚Äô formula: $$ P_n(x) = \frac{1}{2^n n!} \frac{d^n}{dx^n} (x^2 - 1)^n $$ Explicit forms:
  • $P_0(x) = 1$
  • $P_1(x) = x$
  • $P_2(x) = \frac12(3x^2 - 1)$
  • $P_3(x) = \frac12(5x^3 - 3x)$
Orthogonality on $[-1,1]$: $$ \int_{-1}^1 P_m(x) P_n(x)\, dx = 0 \quad (m \neq n), \quad \int_{-1}^1 [P_n(x)]^2\, dx = \frac{2}{2n+1} $$ $\{P_n(x)\}_{n=0}^\infty$ forms an orthogonal basis for polynomials on $[-1,1]$. Expansion: Any polynomial $f(x)$ of degree $\leq n$: $$ f(x) = \sum_{k=0}^n a_k P_k(x), \quad a_k = \frac{2k+1}{2} \int_{-1}^1 f(x) P_k(x)\, dx $$

Frobenius Method (Extended Power Series)

For equations with regular singular point at $x=0$: $$ x^2 y'' + x b(x) y' + c(x) y = 0 \tag{2} $$ where $b(x), c(x)$ analytic at $x=0$ (i.e., $b(x) = \sum bm x^m$, $c(x) = \sum cm x^m$).

Indicial equation (from lowest power $x^r$): $$ I(r) = r(r-1) + b_0 r + c_0 = 0 $$ Frobenius solution: $$ y(x) = x^r \sum_{m=0}^\infty a_m x^m \quad (a_0 \neq 0) $$ Recurrence (for $n \geq 1$): $$ I(r+n) a_n + \sum_{k=0}^{n-1} [ (r+k) b_{n-k} + c_{n-k} ] a_k = 0 $$ Three cases (roots $r_1 \geq r_2$): Case 1: $r_1 - r_2 \notin \mathbb{Z}$ (distinct, not differing by integer) Two independent solutions: $$ y_1(x) = x^{r_1} \sum a_m(r_1) x^m, \quad y_2(x) = x^{r_2} \sum A_m(r_2) x^m $$ Case 2: $r_1 = r_2 = r$ (repeated root) $$ y_1(x) = x^r \sum a_m x^m $$ $$ y_2(x) = y_1(x) \ln x + x^r \sum A_m x^m \quad (x>0) $$ Case 3: $r_1 - r_2 = N \in \mathbb{N}$ (differ by positive integer) $$ y_1(x) = x^{r_1} \sum a_m x^m $$ $$ y_2(x) = k y_1(x) \ln x + x^{r_2} \sum A_m x^m \quad (k \text{ may be } 0) $$

Bessel‚Äôs Equation & Bessel Functions

Bessel‚Äôs equation (order $\nu \geq 0$): $$ x^2 y'' + x y' + (x^2 - \nu^2) y = 0 \tag{3} $$ or $$ y'' + \frac{1}{x} y' + \left(1 - \frac{\nu^2}{x^2}\right) y = 0 $$ Indicial equation: $r^2 - \nu^2 = 0 \implies r = \pm \nu$ Bessel function of first kind (order $n$ integer): $$ J_n(x) = \sum_{m=0}^\infty \frac{(-1)^m}{m! (n+m)!} \left(\frac{x}{2}\right)^{n+2m} $$ General solution (for integer $n$): $$ y(x) = c_1 J_n(x) + c_2 Y_n(x) $$ where $Y_n(x)$ is the Bessel function of the second kind (involves $\ln x$).

Summary of Lectures 9 & 10

  • Power series about arbitrary point: Shift variable or expand directly in $(x-x_0)$.
  • Legendre equation: Power series ‚Üí Legendre polynomials $P_n(x)$ via termination; Rodrigues formula; orthogonal on $[-1,1]$.
  • Frobenius method: Handles regular singular points; indicial equation determines leading exponent $r$; three cases for second solution.
  • Bessel equation: Classic singular-point ODE; solutions $J_\nu(x)$ (first kind) and $Y_\nu(x)$ (second kind).
Key Formulas:
  • Legendre: $P_n(x) = \frac{1}{2^n n!} \frac{d^n}{dx^n}(x^2-1)^n$
  • Frobenius recurrence: $I(r+n)a_n + \sum \dots = 0$
  • Bessel $J_n(x)$ series as above.
Next: Applications of special functions, Sturm-Liouville theory, or systems of ODEs.
